title: Search Technologies in the Critical Path of the Next Generation Internet
segmentation: Ladies and gentlemen, over the last 15 years we have a witness to a search.
Technologies has emerged as one of the killer applications on their Internet.

Hundreds of millions of users are probably using this technology on a daily basis throughout the whole world, and if there is one message I like to you to take away from my short presentation, it must be that my conjecture is, like search technology will still be in the critical path of the next generation Internet and it might even play a more important role.
There is also.
Another very positive message to it that is more conjecture today Pierre, but along the lines of Google and the concern you raise a chain.
Well, what we see now is that if you take a little step back is the way you use or you you navigate on the Internet is very personal user browsing history.
You might use just your memory.
You use bookmarks, real time browsing.
But whenever you want to go out there and find some information, of course you have to go through one of the big players who either Google, Yahoo.
Microsoft or maybe AOL in China.
Unfortunately, you can use Spider, which is at the time may be bigger than any of the other search engines.
We don't really have numbers for that, but the key messages that sources become the portal.
The interface to large scale Internet, but also enterprise data and the very good news.
And now is that we observe that there babe is really getting fragmented when it comes to search technology.

We all tend to think that while Google is a big sort of player out there with some of the other just coming behind but very, very compelling research in particular being done in the US these days by IDC and in particular Sue Feldman.
Has come up with results that indicate that only 1/3 of curious in the US actually goes through this big search portal portals.
That means that 70% of search goes through.
Typical what you see here as customers.
For instance of past.
And if you accumulate just security through that 4000 customers, we have one, Comcast being one of them, which is, I think the 5th or 6th biggest portal on the Internet.
I think it's bigger than even Google to that.
And the good news is that is that users tend to go directly to some of this one, instead of maybe going through the big players.
At least my tablet profound impact on everything from the financial market.
Maybe the financial market hasn't discovered this yet, but there will really be.
You cite some magic.
And also another very important thing is that the technology we developed initially for to big huge datacenters in throughout the world, you cannot actually find it unless he did.
This is a search engine where we put more than 30 million, activate it in in programmer year, zanin programmers in Norway and the US in 2002.
This is a search engine that used to be a more or less competing with Google running on thousands and thousands of computers is down.
Unless it is an industry and what you see is that today is a business intelligence, surveillance and security.
Fraud detection over or about us.
Oxley euros all these type of problems, quality management E Commerce recommendation systems.
All these are being powered by technology coming out of the resource lab from such a company.
Just to give a small example, but you don't tend to think about sources as sort of wrapping and E Commerce solution.

One of the customers were provided the solution exporting technology from Europe to Japan was Rakuten more the eBay of Japan, which actually very you have 100 updates of all the items put into the system.
Every second you have 2000 curies every second.
That is people who want to buy something and you generate there on the order of 2012 million dollars.
Every day of transaction just going through search.
So what is source plan?
Well, we tend to think about it as a very naive interface.
Yes, interface is annoying idea, but it's extremely complex technology running behind that.
Can you think about even without being to technology?
The specialist that he takes you less than .2 seconds to virtually browse through more than 10 billion documents.

Downloading one of the documents they always more than one point or .2 seconds, so there is something out here and I don't have time to go back to that, only they really what I'm telling is that is extremely complex if technology behind.
Another interesting aspect to notice is what the big players have done.
The last five six years.
They've tried to lock in users.
The point is that they provide FREE Email at some causal privacy, of course, and a free storage social networks.
They buy whatever they can buy, and it's all about this battle of the consumers, because the big portals are in the critical path they want to remain in the critical path where the big bucks are.
So some implications of this well is a pervasive technology.
You find it out there not only in the typical Internet usage, but in most of the big enterprises is also a very evolving technology.

Some of the brightest technology people I know has gone to Microsoft Research to Google Apps to autonomy in England to a lot of this, this research labs and industrial companies working on this technology and currently what?

No working up, and in particular my resource group together with Cornell and some other universities is to get rid of the computer I want to use this Stone Age technology where I use the keyboard and ask for information and drill down.
I want to be told by the Internet.
I want to be told about the push infrastructure that in a very context sensitive manner on my cellular.
But this is very important for you though, so that's what we're looking into the next generation search technology, something just behind that hidden in the walls.
I don't care like electricity.
But I'm told on my ear whatever when something happens.
Also is a room for whole separate industry.
We were acquired by Microsoft.
Yes, that is a big industry in Norway we have several companies working and exporting this technology.
Not only all fission treatment also exporting this technology to the whole world is also very vital for the digital marketplaces and this is my message.
We're chasing the advertising ecosystem these days.
You see more and more.
Maybe going into the door.
Through this speciality portals 50% of the US online advertisements go through the big players at least big for once only 1/3 of the curious.
When will the financial market discover that something is all here?
We discovered?
A very strong concern I have, which was raised by Bill and owner today, so this privacy, preservation of privacy this is light pollution will leave traces out there, including the search engines.
It's amazing to see whole naive users are.
I don't trust anybody more or less out there.
I mean, we might come back to the panel later on this issue, but he's really like PCB and pollution in the 50s and 60s.
We didn't care, but one day we have to care.
Social and Contra Iambi suggest telling that is very important.
The trend we see today where the users are really being socially activated where there are being put more on the web, not by regular public response by regular users.
I'd like you and me and our kids.
But also there might be some some culture and social things like conformity uses are assaulted by swayed by the taste of others.
You have new concepts like like viral marketing, where you going through social networking, identify one person at a time you can have or she can have impact on the social group.
Various carriers use the locking by giving away your identity and your whole history or your rights for whatever you're producing, just to have a few players to do that.
No, we must have alternative.
Magnification I'm not scared anymore.
Well I'm going to reach it.
I've never scared we see the Chinese.
We see a very good efforts in France and Germany in England.
Well throughout the whole world where there will be other players.
There will not be a monopoly.
With that said, thank you.
